new_marks.note: Was the patient who was reported as potentially cured of HIV in February 2022 the first woman to be potentially cured?
new_marks.check: True. Hsu et al (2022) provide the first observational study of HIV remission in a woman. The abstract for the study (number 65, IMPAACT P1107) can be found here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf

range.commonAncestorContainer: First woman reported cured of HIV after stem cell transplant
range.commonAncestorContainerReal: First woman reported cured of HIV after stem cell transplant

new_marks.note: Were stem cells the medium through which the latest patient (as of February 2022) was potentially cured?
new_marks.check: True. According to the abstract provided by Hsu et al (2022), “We report on a woman in ART-free HIV-1 remission for 14 months following CCR5∆32 homozygous cord blood (CB) and CD34-selected haploidentical stem cell transplant (haplo-cord SCT) for acute myeloid leukemia (AML).” Find the rest of the abstract here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

range.startContainer: CHICAGO, Feb 15 (Reuters) - A U.S. patient with leukemia has become the first woman and the third person to date to be cured of HIV after receiving a stem cell transplant from a donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported on Tuesday.
range.startContainerReal: CHICAGO, Feb 15 (Reuters) - A U.S. patient with leukemia has become the first woman and the third person to date to be cured of HIV after receiving a stem cell transplant from a donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported on Tuesday.

range.endContainerReal: CHICAGO, Feb 15 (Reuters) - A U.S. patient with leukemia has become the first woman and the third person to date to be cured of HIV after receiving a stem cell transplant from a donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported on Tuesday.
range.endText: after receiving a stem cell transplant from a donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported on Tuesday.
range.commonAncestorContainer: CHICAGO, Feb 15 (Reuters) - A U.S. patient with leukemia has become the first woman and the third person to date to be cured of HIV after receiving a stem cell transplant from a donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported on Tuesday.
range.commonAncestorContainerReal: CHICAGO, Feb 15 (Reuters) - A U.S. patient with leukemia has become the first woman and the third person to date to be cured of HIV after receiving a stem cell transplant from a donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS, researchers reported on Tuesday.

new_marks.note: Was the latest patient to be potentially cured of HIV (as of February 2022) treated in the US?
new_marks.check: True. This patient was treated as part of IMPAACT P1107, "an observational study of persons living with HIV in the U.S. who undergo transplantation with CCR5Δ32 cord blood stem cells for treatment of cancer or other illness," according to its website (https://www.impaactnetwork.org/news/2022/impaact-p1107-team-presents-first-known-case-woman-hiv-remission). Information about the status of IMPAACT P1107 as a clinical trial are available here: https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02140944.

new_marks.check: True. Hsu et al (2022) provide the first observational study of HIV remission in a woman. The abstract for the study (number 65, IMPAACT P1107) can be found here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.note: Was the February 2022 patient the third person to be potentially cured of HIV?
new_marks.check: True. In addition to the current patient, there were two previous patients who were reported cured of HIV. The studies of the three patients are summarized in the Hutter et al (2009) (https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0802905), Gupta et al (2019) (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1027-4), and Hsu et al (2022) (https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf, #65), respectively.
new_marks.highlight: third person to date to be cured of HIV

new_marks.note: Was the stem cell donor to the February 2022 patient naturally resistant to HIV?
new_marks.check: True. Hsu et al (2022) report that this patient has been treated with umbilical cord blood containing a mutation that is known to be resistant to HIV infection. See Schmidt et al (1996) for foundational results about this resistance: https://www.nature.com/articles/382722a0.
new_marks.highlight: donor who was naturally resistant to the virus that causes AIDS

new_marks.note: Which researchers reported that the February 2022 patient was potentially cured of HIV?
new_marks.check: True. The team that reported the latest HIV cure is composed of researchers. Their names are JingMei Hsu, Koen Van Besien, Marshall J. Glesby, Anne Coletti, Savita G. Pahwa, Meredith Warshaw, Amanda Golner, Frederic Bone, Nicole Tobin, Marcie Riches, John W. Mellors, Renee Browning, Deborah Persaud, and Yvonne Bryson. Their institutional affiliations can be found here: https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.note: Did the 2022 Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunisitic [sic] Infections take place in Denver?
new_marks.check: Somewhat false. Although the 2022 Conference on Retroviruses and Opportunistic Infections was scheduled to take place in person in Denver, it was converted to a fully virtual conference. The conference organizers issued refunds to participants who registered for in-person attendance: https://www.croiconference.org/croi-2022-refunds-for-converting-an-in-person-to-virtual-registration-will-begin-processing-next-week.

new_marks.note: Was the February 2022 patient's case the "first involving umbilical cord blood?"
new_marks.check: True. Of the patients considered cured of HIV/AIDS, this patient is the first whose cure involved umbilical cord blood. See Hsu et al (2018) for more details: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755.

new_marks.note: Did the February 2022 patient receive the cord blood to treat her acute myeloid leukemia?
new_marks.check: True. Hsu et al (2018) and Hsu et al (2022) describe this patient's treatment for acute myeloid leukemia (AML) in the following, respective studies: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755 and https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.
new_marks.highlight: receiving the cord blood to treat her acute myeloid leukemia

range.startContainer: Since receiving the cord blood to treat her acute myeloid leukemia - a cancer that starts in blood-forming cells in the bone marrow - the woman has been in remission and free of the virus for 14 months, without the need for potent HIV treatments known as antiretroviral therapy.

new_marks.check: True. Lowenberg et al (1999) describe acute myeloid leukemia here: https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/nejm199909303411407.

new_marks.note: Did the February 2022 patient enter remission in December 2020?
new_marks.check: Somewhat true. According to the timeline outlined by Hsu et al (2018) and Hsu et al (2022, #65), this patient's remission (14 months after stopping ART) began in November or December 2021. The patient would have stopped ART in or around September 2020. The respective studies are available using the following links: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755, https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.
new_marks.highlight: in remission and free of the virus for 14 months

range.commonAncestorContainerReal: Since receiving the cord blood to treat her acute myeloid leukemia - a cancer that starts in blood-forming cells in the bone marrow - the woman has been in remission and free of the virus for 14 months, without the need for potent HIV treatments known as antiretroviral therapy.

new_marks.note: Has the February 2022 patient been without antiretroviral therapy since December 2020?
new_marks.check: Somewhat true. According to the timeline outlined by Hsu et al (2018) and Hsu et al (2022, #65), this patient's remission (14 months after stopping ART) began in November or December 2021. The patient would have stopped ART in or around September 2020. The respective studies are available using the following links: https://ashpublications.org/blood/article/132/Supplement%201/2184/261755, https://www.iasusa.org/wp-content/uploads/2022/03/30-1s-3.pdf.

new_marks.note: Were the two people who were potentially cured of HIV prior to the February 2022 men?
new_marks.check: True. Hutter et al (2009) shows that the first patient, known as the "Berlin Patient" was a man (https://www.nejm.org/doi/full/10.1056/NEJMoa0802905) and Gupta et al (2019) states that the second patient, known as the "London Patient", was a man (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-019-1027-4).
new_marks.highlight: The two prior cases occurred in males

range.startContainer: The two prior cases occurred in males - one white and one Latino - who had received adult stem cells, which are more frequently used in bone marrow transplants.
range.startContainerReal: The two prior cases occurred in males - one white and one Latino - who had received adult stem cells, which are more frequently used in bone marrow transplants.

new_marks.note: Speculation. Expert opinion, but opinion nonetheless.

new_marks.highlight: There’s something magical about these cells and something magical perhaps about the cord blood in general that provides an extra benefit

range.startContainer: “Umbilical stem cells are attractive,” Dr. Deeks said. “There’s something magical about these cells and something magical perhaps about the cord blood in general that provides an extra benefit.”
